I agree with you partially, as in yes it's not gonna happen if you have zero technical skills, but I think that you don't need "amazing" technical skills to reach the sufficient quality that electronic music nowadays requires, you need experience to learn/understand the absolute basics of what you're doing.
Looking back at my tracks, it took a short time for me to vastly improve my work quality when I started realising where I'd been fucking up all along, rather than putting more work into it.

Here, watch this, Jay Hardway breaking down his track Electric Elephants. In the video he talks about how he works more like a composer and less as a producer.
youtube.com/watch?v=6dxanyRBeRQ client=mv-google gl=US hl=en
On communities including this one he received flak for a previous tutorial he did where he said he didn't really know what a compressor does. Communities like this one here focus a lot on the technical aspects of production, and it's natural BUT you shouldn't feel like you can't make good electronic music unless you're Nicky Romero incarnate. I suggest watching the vid I linked above and seeing how he works, because his way of production is focused mainly on the musical element itself, using the tools in the DAW without getting too deep and stressing about the technicalities. Imho you CAN make good sounds and good music relying on your 'musicality' more than your technicality.

There's a minority of wizards living everywhere right alongside muggles. Diagon Alley isn't the only place in the entire wizarding world, we see only that particular place because it's closest to where Harry lived. There's organisations like the wizarding newspapers/magazines, the Ministry of Magic, other schools themselves, hospitals, basically equivalents of muggle things everywhere.

The master plan involved Malfoy disarming Dumbledore to become the actual owner of the wand, and Voldemort THINKING it was Snape because Snape was the one who killed Voldemort. So Voldemort would think he'd have to kill Snape to become the owner of the Elder Wand, whereas in reality Snape never was the owner, but he'd have to sacrifice himself, like Ron in the chess board.

Snape's death was part of Dumbledore's master plan. So was Harry's.
And both deaths were meant to lead to Voldemort's death.

No , Ableton is not the standard. It has come to the point right now where choosing DAWs is just a matter of workflow, aesthetics and opinion. Just google Ableton vs FL Studio and you'll quickly come to know. Additionally, the most widely used DAW in electronic and hip hop production is easily FL Studio. FL Studio has a much gentler learning curve over Ableton too. Plus a much lower price tag.
Edit: quick googling tells me that FL is actually not the MOST prevalent. I was speaking from personal observation.

WRITING.TITLE: [TOMT] [SONG] Female vocals, can't remember anything else but the melody I've linked
WRITING.TEXT:
I guess this is a fairly recent song, I'm guessing this year or the last, at the latest. Here's what I could recreate to the best of my ability :c https://clyp.it/pq3mvkm5
It's fairly famous so I'm expecting success here. Been stuck in my head too long.
EDIT: A bit more description: the song in question was fairly slow paced and sort of melancholic, I remember just a bit of the video and I think it was a couple in a house messing around or something. The chorus consists of the singer going 'whoaaa-ohhhhh-oh-oh' consistent with the 4 separated notes you can hear in the clip at 7 seconds. The singer's voice is similar to AlunaGeorge, but it's not her, I've checked.
Solved edit: /u/coranns nailed it! It was [New Scene by Felix Cartal](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mGCq9n18H4U). I can now live in peace. Thanks to everyone who replied!
